comments.commentBody: One only has to recall the first words of Neil Armstrong on landing on moon "That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind." Now you see the real spin-off the NASA investment in space research for the mankind in form of this NASA designed capsule to rescue these miners(otherwise an almost hopeless case) in Chile mines.There are several other technological wonders that has come in day to day use ,thanks to NASA.
Congratulations to the miners, their families and all the rescuers. Truly an outstanding accomplishment. The way the whole world is watching and hoping, it reminds me of Apollo 13.

October 12, 2010 - 11:40 pm NYC EDST

This night in Chile of October 12, 2010 conquers a media event comparable to the July 20, 1969 Apollo 11 moon landing yet its technical engineering accomplishment is in the inverse.

Humanity is seen around the world at its very best; thirty three times in blessings.
One up at this hour and all remaining to surface - God willing.

Faith, hope, and a great and excellent Plan B, and billions of well wishers on our planet is living a gracefully and beautifully story to witness, share, and learn, that this is what can be done when we live, and work in harmony mindfully of our brothers and sisters.

Joseph Amato
Manhattan, N. Y.
Prayers answered. Poet's grace and speed.

Fingers crossed all the way until everyone is brought back to safety!! On another note, President Sebastian Pinera of Chile is taking such a shameless advantage of this terrible desperate situation - that´s the downside of this story.

Once again, so proud of my countrymen!

First the earthquake, now this amazing rescue.

For a country considered to be "third world", we do pretty damn good. More countries around the world should take notes.

VIVA CHILE!

My wife and I were lucky to read about the Maxxi Museum when we picked up a copy of the October 2010 issue of 'ROMA - A Guest In Rome,' free at hotels.  So, we put a visit on our list of things to do.  Tuesday's are free admission for seniors.  Regular admission is 11 Euro at $1.38 to 1 Euro, it's $15.18 USA.  So, we were lucky selecting our visit on October 12, 2010.  The museum is located in the Flamino area reached by underground Metro (subway) exit by Piazza Popolo - Flamino Station.  Then by Tram #2 - 4 stops. It's a long walk from the Metro. As we walked down the street after exiting Tram #2, we were blown away by the massive 'skeleton,'  laying on its back at the entrance to the museum.  The building is beautifully designed by Zaha Hadid.  Its awesome.  There are small chairs throughout the museum to take a break.  A very small gift shop.  No postcards available.  No photos are permitted.  Woman with large purses must check them in (free). There's an outdoor courtyard near the cafeteria with a lot of chairs to relax tired feet after leaving the museum.  We enjoyed our 3 hours at the museum, especially the permanent exhibition by Italian Architect Luici Moretti, on the first floor of the three floor museum.  Luici Moretti, designed Watergate in Washington, D.C.  There's a small model of Watergate and its story but not the famous' break in' story.  There's an English version for every exhibit -- something you don't find in too many tourists sites in Rome.  Put it on your list and bring a camera to photograph the outside of the building. Michael Zullo, Upper Eastside, Manhattan

I went from subscribing to Center Ice on DirecTV when I "lived" in North Carolina (wink-wink) a few years ago to getting Centre Ice on Rogers Cable for a few years. I was frustrated that I couldn't watch MSG feeds of Ranger games in HD, so I was thrilled when I subscribed to NHL GameCenter Live at NHL.com. Nice to get the MSG feed in HD—finally. Looks great. If only I could say the same thing about their Stanley Cup chances this season.

For Probber, it was frustrating when Rogers would rarely pick up any HD feeds for NHL games when on many nights I could get six or seven MLB games in HD.

Of course it matters who the boy is. It matters as much as the identities of those who died on 911. If it didn't matter, why bother reading out the names of 3000 people, year after year. It matters because people loved those who died. They had mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, children, partners; they had a life. They were not symbols, anymore than this boy is a symbol. He was a child, playing one day, on a train to a death camp another. Enjoy the mystery if you want, but giving this boy a name means that all the others who died also had names. Tim in Winnipeg, the same impulse that wants to reduce a child to a symbol is the same impulse that allows us to ignore global warming or human sex-trafficking. Until we start adding up the cost to each and every individual, we will never know the real price we pay for distancing ourselves from subject matter that we find hard to swallow. Abstraction is a coward's game.

It pains me to see an empty area where Yankee Stadium used to be ( I call the new place
"Yankee Theme Park".) Not only baseball, but American history was made and played there --
and I spent many happy days there through my life. I agree with an earlier comment that
the "House that Ruth Built" should be named for him -- and perhaps Mr. Fein's photo could
be beautifully displayed therein.

The photographic is iconic. It needs no survivor to come forward to explain what was happening. The young boy represents "innocence" slaughtered by mindless hatred.  The world was never the same after this single photograph came to light.

Question of the day: Can Asta play Canasta?

By coincidence we have two cats, and because of a rash under their chins we have been giving them medicine from a dropper twice a day for the last several days. So I am familiar with the cat tackle.

I can pronounce the city of Glen Campbell's lineman, but I sure had trouble getting the right letters.

I've been around boats quite a bit, but have never heard of a cat tackle.

Here's a link that might help: http://books.google.com...

-- jpgaskell

I found the link below about today's crossword and thought it very cute and funny

http://theimaginedaristocracy.wordpress.com...

I thought I saw a split T formation in the grid, but now I see it is an illegal formation.. Things were tight on my end for awhile, but I put the theme in motion and Snap! I was in the end zone. Any one else's Happy Pencil have both hands raised over his head?

I'm with Arthur118 on this one. I was fine with the theme but the fill was pretty ordinary and relied some on crosswordese. I did like MYRIAD, IN SHAPE AND ON TOP OF (especially next to each other), CHORTLE, and IN A MOOD.

Didn't care for seeing ASTI and ASTA in one puzzle and ALI and IDO seem to be getting lots of air time lately.

This one seems more like a Tuesday. But truly, any puzzle would suffer in comparison to yesterday's.

Other excellent news...my Reds are gone, but the Texas Rangers advanced to the next round of the playoffs...for the first time ever. Gutsy base running, but can they defeat The Evil Empire?
A.J. Burnett, the man for the job?  You gotta be kidding me.  I hope he's on a very very short leash.

I was 12 in 1972. The great single event that year was Steve Carlton being traded from the Cardinals to the Phillies for Rick Wise (everyone was made because Wise was the best pitcher on the staff and pitched a no-hiiter the previous season). Carlton went 27-10 and everyone forgot about Rick Wise. (The Phillies won 59 games that year) highest percentage of single pitcher to total team wins ever (46 percent). Carlton's ERA was 1.97.

No one dominated like that ever. Almost unhittable after June of that year (Willie Stargell on hitting against Carlton-- "like trying to drink coffee with a fork")

The Phillies stunk. They were a lousy hitting team, but above average in fielding.

Lesson: If you can pitch and you catch the ball you can be very competitive. The game gets real simple when you only need to score two runs per game to have a decent shot at winning.

This is a note to the Atlanta Braves, who can pitch, but forgot how to catch the ball throughout the division series.

I guess some of you want to see Andy actually pitch til his arm falls off, of course there was going to be a 4th starter. Look at the upside, if Burnett pitches well it'll make it easier to trade him after the season.
If we can make AJ believe a shaving cream pie is a baseball, and a Yankee player face the corners of a strike zone, he may have a chance.

Mugsy is right. Don't second guess Girardi. He has proven he knows how to win.

GO Yankees!!! GO AJ!!!

The negative over-reaction to letting AJ Burnt-Out throw an inning or two in the ALCS is unnecessary because he will either do a good job, or be out of the game in the third inning. If the Yankees face the Rays, Burnt-Out will go against either Shields, Garza or a #4 just like him; a similar match-up would happen versus the Rangers.

However, let's also recall that Burnett was signed because of what he CAN do and because of what he has done in the past. Sometimes, long layoffs provide long self-improvement sessions, which lead to actual improvement. There is no reason for Burnett to continue to pitch poorly --- and, as a matter of fact, he has done quite well against Texas this year.

Let's stop thinking negative and start the positive. Recall the Donald Sutherland flick, "Kelly's Heroes?" As Sutherland's character used to say, "Enough with those negatives waves man. Think of good things."

This is the right call.  AJ will only have a short leash - If Burnett gets into even a bit of trouble early, Girardi will be quick to call on a platoon of Mitre, Moseley and the rest of the bull pen.  I suspect Burnett is going to prove a lot of people wrong.

I'm looking forward to a Giants vs. Yankees WS...a rematch of 1962 ! (Except this time maybe game 7 ends with A-Rod lining out to Freddy Sanchez with the winning run on second.)

Go Jints !
no words will suffice.
